snippet: The National Security Agency has secretly circumvented or cracked much of the digital scrambling that protects global commerce, e-mails, phone calls, medical records and Web searches.
abstract: Documents provided by Edward J Snowden show the National Security Agency is winning its long-running secret war on encryption, using supercomputers, technical trickery, court orders and persuasion to undermine major tools protecting privacy of everyday communications; agency has secretly circumvented or cracked much of the digital scrambling that protects global commerce, e-mails, phone calls, medical records and Web searches.

byline.original: By NICOLE PERLROTH, JEFF LARSON and SCOTT SHANE
byline.contributor:
This article was reported in partnership
by The New York Times,
The Guardian and ProPublica
based on documents obtained by
The Guardian. For The Guardian:
James Ball, Julian Borger, Glenn
Greenwald. For The Times: Nicole
Perlroth, Scott Shane. For Pro-
Publica: Jeff Larson.; John Markoff contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency has secretly circumvented or cracked much of the digital scrambling that protects global commerce, e-mails, phone calls, medical records and Web searches.

headline.main: N.S.A. Able to Foil Basic Safeguards of Privacy on Web
headline.print_headline: N.S.A. Able To Foil Basic Safeguards Of Privacy On Web
